name: Ramda ‚Äì A practical functional library for JavaScript that is designed specifically for a functional programming style. A style that makes it easy to create functional pipelines and never mutates user data. +TS.
Ramda Adjunct is a community-maintained extension of Ramda.
Ramda-extension is set of utility point-free functions composed only from Ramda functions.
Rambda
description: A faster alternative to Ramda in under 10kB.

name: Rambdax
description: Extended version of Rambda

name: Folktale ‚Äì A standard library for functional programming in JavaScript. Typescript support expected mid-2020.  -TS.
lodash/fp ‚Äì An instance of Lodash with its methods wrapped to produce immutable, auto-curried, iteratee-first, data-last methods. +TS.
functional.js ‚Äì A lightweight functional JavaScript library that facilitates currying and point-free / tacit programming.
101 ‚Äì A modern and modular JavaScript utility library made to work well with vanilla JavaScript methods.  -TS
fnuc ‚Äì A functional library for CoffeeScript (and JavaScript) to facilitate functional composition and higher order functions.
barely-functional ‚Äì A tiny (2.7kb) functional programming library using native ES5/6 operations. -TS.
bluebird-promisell
description: A practical functional programming library for promises.

name: prelude.ls ‚Äì A functionally oriented utility library somewhat based off of Haskell's Prelude module. -TS.
preludejs
description: Hardcore Functional Programming for JavaScript. -TS.

name: 1-liners ‚Äì Functional tools that couldn‚Äôt be simpler. A dead simple functional utility belt, hand-crafted with love and attention.  -TS.
fn-curry ‚Äì A simple function to curry a function.
curry ‚Äì Curry your functions using function bind syntax.
compose-function ‚Äì Compose a new function from smaller functions.
functionize ‚Äì A collection of functions which aid in making non-functional libraries functional.
lambdajs ‚Äì The full ECMAScript API done a functional way.
fp-dom ‚Äì Making the DOM functional.
react-on-lambda
description: Replace JSX in React with functions (currying, compositions and etc).

name: trifl ‚Äì A functional user interface library with unidirectional dataflow and a virtual dom.
funcy ‚Äì An experiment in adding functional pattern matching to JavaScript. Experimental  üö©
date-fp ‚Äì A functional utility library for working with JavaScript dates. All functions in date-fp are pure, autocurried and will not mutate the date objects they are applied to.
js-joda ‚Äì An immutable date and time library that provides a simple, domain-driven and clean API based on the ISO8601 calendar.
_part_ ‚Äì A micro library that encourages functional programming by making native methods available as partially applied functions.
claire ‚Äì A property-based testing library for clearly specifying code invariants and behaviour.
FPO.js ‚Äì FP library for JavaScript by Kyle Simpson (aka getify). Supports named-argument style methods.
Javascript Parser Combinator ‚Äì Javascript parser combinator implementation inspired by the Haskell's Parsec

fun-task ‚Äì An abstraction for managing asynchronous code in JS. Tasks are similar to Promises with the key difference that Tasks can represent a computation while Promises can represent only the results of a computation. Ships with Flow type definitions.
most ‚Äì Ultra-high performance reactive programming to help you compose asynchronous operations on streams of values and events without many of the hazards of side effects and mutable shared state.
zen-signals ‚Äì ‚òØ The simplest signal library possible
funfix ‚Äì Funfix is a library of type classes and data types for Functional Programming in JavaScript, TypeScript and Flow.  +CT, +TS.

hm-def ‚Äì Runtime type checking for JS with Hindley Milner signatures.
ftor
description: A pluggable runtime type checker and functional debugging tool that supports parametric and row polymorphism, implicit rank-2 types and algebraic data types via Scott Encoding.

name: Professor Frisby‚Äôs Mostly Adequate Guide to Functional Programming ‚Äì This is a book on the functional paradigm in general using the world‚Äôs most popular functional programming language: JavaScript. It‚Äôs a practical introduction that builds up intuition through real-world examples. Strongly recommended. By Brian Lonsdorf (2016)

Functional-Light JavaScript ‚Äì This book explores the core principles of functional programming (FP) that can be applied to JavaScript. But what makes this book different is that it approaches these principles without all the heavy terminology.

JavaScript Allong√©, the ‚ÄúSix‚Äù edition. Starts with as little as possible about functions ‚Äì but no less! ‚Äì and builds up towards powerful combinators and decorators. A foundational book. By Reginald  Braithwaite (2016)

Functional Programming in JavaScript teaches JavaScript developers functional techniques that will improve extensibility, modularity, reusability, testability, and performance. Through concrete examples and jargon-free explanations, this book teaches you how to apply functional programming to real-life development tasks. By Luis Atencio (2016)
Eloquent JavaScript. A modern introduction to programming using JavaScript. By Marijn Haverbeke (2014)
Functional JavaScript teaches how to create code that‚Äôs beautiful, safe, and simple to understand and test by using JavaScript‚Äôs functional programming support. By Michael Fogus (2013)
Grokking Simplicity teaches functional programming from first principles. It uses JavaScript for all code examples and it uses real-world scenarios. By Eric Normand (2019)
scriptum
description: a no-frills functional programming library and a online course based on it

name: FP Concepts in JavaScript ‚Äì An introduction to Functional Programming Concepts in JavaScript. Uses the Ramda library to teach the concepts of composition, pointfree style, and functors through the simplest of examples.

Functional programming with JavaScript ‚Äì Another introduction to Functional Programming in JavaScript with a focus on three key themes: computation as the application of functions, statelessness, avoiding side effects.

A gentle introduction to functional JavaScript ‚Äì A four-part series introduction functional programming in JavaScript that gets you up to speed what all the hype about functional programming is all about.
Functors from first principle
description: explained with JS - Explaining functors concept using JavaScript.

name: Why Curry Helps ‚Äì A short overview of how to write reusable and declarative code using currying.
Favoring Curry
description: Practical applications of currying using Ramda.

name: Functional Mumbo Jumbo ‚Äì ADTs ‚Äì A beginner-friendly introduction to Algebraic Data Types.
JavaScript and Type Thinking ‚Äì Learn to reason about your JavaScript code with type thinking. Algebraic Data Types are introduced as a conceptual basis to reason about program entities.

Lazy, composable, and modular JavaScript ‚Äì Use four new features of ES6 ‚Äì iterables, generators, fat arrows, and for-of ‚Äì in conjunction with higher-order functions, function composition, and lazy evaluation, to write cleaner and more modular JavaScript.

Why Ramda ‚Äì To those not used to functional programming, Ramda seems to serve no purpose whatsoever. However, it does offer a different style of coding, a style that‚Äôs taken for granted in purely functional programming languages: Ramda makes it simple for you to build complex logic through functional composition.
Monads in JavaScript ‚Äì An introduction to the Monad design pattern in JavaScript.

A Monad in Practicality: First-Class Failures ‚Äì A walk through some practical use cases for specific monadic structures in JavaScript: use the Maybe monad to handle simple failure cases and model more complex scenarios with the Either monad or the Validation applicative functor.
Functional programming ‚Äì Many articles on various aspects of functional programming in JavaScript by Gleb Bahmutov.
Functional Programming Jargon ‚Äì Jargon from the functional programming world explained in JavaScript.
Data Structures in JavaScript ‚Äì A series of blog posts that reimplements various data structures in JavaScript to better understand their benefits and downsides.
So You Want to be a Functional Programmer
description: Easy to understand, with some examples, introduction to Functional Programming in Javascript and Elm.
